p.text: [Pt 7 insrt Act 196 of 1979 s 5 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 195] s 195 Order to Judge or officer

p.text: If a Judge or officer of the Court refuses to do any act relating to the duties of his or her office, the Supreme Court may, on the application of any party requiring the act to be done, by order direct the Judge or officer to do the act.
[s 195 (formerly s 176) insrt Act 196 of 1979 s 5 and Sch 1 ; am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 195.5] Orders in nature of mandamus

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 195.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 195.

The corresponding section of the former Act, s 147 , prohibited the issue of mandamus, but substituted a power in the Supreme Court to grant an order exactly similar to mandamus without the technicalities: Re Australian Timber Workers' Union; Ex parte Veneer Co Ltd (1936) 37 SR (NSW) 52 at 59 .

An order may be made under this section whenever a judge or officer withholds compliance and refuses to do what is properly required of him in the discharge of his judicial office: R v Brecknock & Abergavenny Canal Navigation Co (1835) 3 AD & E 217; 111 ER 395; R v Bristol & Exeter Railway Co (1843) 4 QB 162; 114 ER 859; Ex parte McAuley; Re Cam (1944) 44 SR (NSW) 258 ; Ex parte Williams; Re Moore [1960] NSWR 588; (1960) 77 WN (NSW) 269 .

Local examples of the operation of s 195 may be found in White v Bank of New South Wales (1862) 1 SCR (NSW) 159; Ex parte Conway (1868) 7 SCR (NSW) 209; Ex parte Spence (1871) 11 SCR (NSW) 48; White v Union Trustee Co of Australia Ltd (1909) 9 SR (NSW) 253. For English examples: see Davis v Pearce (1870) LR 5 CP 435; Thornewell v Wigner (1871) LR 6 Ex 87; Blades v Lawrence (1874) LR 9 QB 374; R v Philbrick; Ex parte Edwards [1905] 2 KB 108 and R v Judge Lailey; Ex parte Koffman [1932] 1 KB 568.
No privilege shall be allowed to any Australian legal practitioner or other person to exempt the Australian legal practitioner or other person from the provisions of this Act.
[s 196 (formerly s 177) insrt Act 196 of 1979 s 5 and Sch 1; am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3; Act 58 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 3.4[6], effective 20 June 2006]

The purpose of this section is to make it clear that the ancient rule that an officer of a superior court had the privilege of only being sued or being sued in such a court does not apply to the NSW District Court: Day v Ward (1886) 17 QBD 703 .
In this section, “proclamation” means a proclamation under this Act, not being the proclamation under section 2 .
A power conferred by any provision of this Act to make a proclamation includes the power to revoke or amend that proclamation from time to time.
A proclamation shall—
be published in the Gazette; and
take effect on and from the date of publication or a later date specified in the proclamation.
[s 197 (formerly s 178) insrt Act 196 of 1979 s 5 and Sch 1]
[s 198 rep Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 6]
In this section, contemnor means a person guilty or alleged to be guilty of contempt of court committed in the face of the Court or in the hearing of the Court.
Where it is alleged, or appears to the Court on its own view, that a person is guilty of contempt of court committed in the face of the Court or in the hearing of the Court, the Court may—
by oral order direct that the contemnor be brought before the Court; or
issue a warrant for the arrest of the contemnor.
Where the contemnor is brought before the Court, the Court shall—
cause the contemnor to be informed orally of the contempt with which the or she is charged;
require the contemnor to make his or her defence to the charge;
after hearing the contemnor, determine the matter of the charge; and
make an order for the punishment or discharge of the contemnor.
[subs (3) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
The Court may, pending disposal of the charge—
direct that the contemnor be kept in such custody as the Court may determine; or
direct that the contemnor be released,
and such a direction is sufficient authority for the contemnor's being kept in custody or released, as the case may be.

The Court may give a direction under subsection (4)(b) on terms, which may include a requirement that the contemnor give security, in such sum as the Court directs, for his or her appearance in person to answer the charge.
[subs (5) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
A warrant for the arrest or detention under this section of a contemnor shall be addressed to the Sheriff or a bailiff and may be issued under the hand of the Judge constituting the Court.
[subs (6) am Act 20 of 1988 s 3 and Sch 4]
The Court may punish contempt by a fine not exceeding 20 penalty units or by imprisonment for a period not exceeding 28 days.
[subs (7) am Act 71 of 1991 s 2 and Sch 1]

The Court may make an order for punishment on terms, including a suspension of punishment or a suspension of punishment in case the contemnor gives security in such manner and in such sum as the Court may approve for good behaviour and performs the terms of the security.
[s 199 insrt Act 196 of 1979 s 5 and Sch 1]
Legislation cited in [DCA s 199.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 199, s 203.

Nothing in the CPA or the UCPR limits or otherwise affects the power of the court to attach or commit a person for contempt: CPA s 131. The District Court has two procedures when dealing with contempt of court. The first, under s 199 , is limited to cases where the contempt is in the face of the court or the hearing of the court: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 1) (1991) 25 NSWLR 459 at 462 : Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435 at 442 [16]; 162 ALR 336 at 340; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 . Such a contempt usually must have been perceived by the judge: European Asian Bank AG v Wentworth (1986) 5 NSWLR 445 at 458; Fraser v R [1984] 3 NSWLR 212; (1984) 15 A Crim R 58 . The second procedure is to refer the matter to the Supreme Court in accordance with DCA s 203 .

No order should be made requiring a defence to the charge of contempt without first giving the person the opportunity to be heard as to why the order should not be made: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 1) (1991) 25 NSWLR 459 at 464 ; cf Skouvakis v Skouvakis [1976] 2 NSWLR 29 at 32.
Legislation cited in [DCA s 199.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 33.12.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 194.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 52, 53.
Particular provisions regarding disobedience to subpoenas are dealt with in UCPR r 33.12 and Evidence Act 1995 s 194 . Contempt in the context of arbitrations are dealt with in CPA ss 52 and 53 .
A fine imposed under section 199 is payable to the registrar for such proclaimed place as the Court directs.

Payment of a fine imposed under section 199 may, if the Court so orders, be enforced, subject to the civil or criminal procedure rules, as if the amount of the fine were a judgment debt, the person upon whom the fine was imposed were a judgment debtor and the registrar were a judgment creditor.
[subs (2) am Act 41 of 1982 Sch 2 ; Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 6]
The amount of any fine paid to or recovered by the registrar under this section shall be paid to the Consolidated Fund.
[subs (3) am Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 8]
[s 200 insrt Act 196 of 1979 s 5 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 201] s 201 Appeals respecting contempt proceedings

p.text: An appeal shall lie at the instance of the contemnor to the Supreme Court from the ruling, order, direction or decision of the Court under section 199 , other than for the discharge of the contemnor.
An appeal under this section shall be made in such manner and be subject to such conditions as may be prescribed by rules of the Supreme Court.
In an appeal under this section, the Supreme Court may affirm, vary or revoke the ruling, order, direction or decision appealed against or may substitute its own ruling, order, direction or decision.
[s 201 insrt Act 196 of 1979 s 5 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 202] s 202 Stay of contempt proceedings

p.text: At any stage of any proceedings under section 199 or 200 , the Court may, on terms, order that the proceedings be stayed.

Where the Court orders that proceedings be stayed under subsection (1) and an appeal is brought under section 201 , the stay of proceedings shall continue until the appeal is disposed of or until the Court or the Supreme Court otherwise orders.
Except as provided in this section or as directed by the Supreme Court, an appeal under section 201 shall not operate as a stay of proceedings.
[s 202 insrt Act 196 of 1979 s 5 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 203] s 203 Power to refer allegation, etc, of contempt to Supreme Court

leg:heading.title: Power to refer allegation, etc, of contempt to Supreme Court

p.text: Without prejudice to the powers of the District Court under section 199 , where it is alleged, or appears to the District Court on its own view, that a person is guilty of contempt of court, whether committed in the face or hearing of the District Court or not, the District Court may refer the matter to the Supreme Court for determination.
On any matter being referred to the Supreme Court under subsection (1) , the Supreme Court shall dispose of the matter in such manner as it considers appropriate.
[s 203 insrt Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 6]
Legislation cited in [DCA s 203.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 203.

Nothing in the CPA or the UCPR limits or otherwise affects the power of the court to attach or commit a person for contempt: s 131 CPA. However, the power under s 203 does not extend to giving the District Court authority to hear and determine contempt proceedings. It is limited to a reference to the Supreme Court: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 1) (1991) 25 NSWLR 459 at 463, 464–5 . Apart from cases of contempt of court committed in the face of the Court or in the hearing of the Court dealt with by DCA s 199, there is no authority on a District Court judge to refer a contempt to the Supreme Court except under s 203 : Lin v Borrowdale [2011] NSWCA 65; BC201101475 at [3] per Young JA. The section involves a procedure of first determining whether there is a contempt, then affording the person an opportunity to show why the matter should not be referred, and finally exercising a discretion whether to refer the matter or not: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 1), aboveat 469 : Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435 at 442 [17]; 162 ALR 336 at 340; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 . A reference under s 203 is not a “judgment or order” accordingly neither the reference, nor a refusal to refer, attracts the right of appeal provided for in DCA s 127: Johnson v Nationwide News Pty Ltd (2005) 62 NSWLR 309; [2005] NSWCA 17; BC200500868 .

For the power to be exercised it must first be alleged or appear to the court that a person is guilty of contempt of court. It may be appropriate for the judge to detail or outline the facts said to give rise to the contempt and ask the person whether he or she disputes any of them: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 1) (1991) 25 NSWLR 459 at 470 : Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435 at 442 [17]; 162 ALR 336 at 340; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 . Where the order made by the District Court is a nullity the failure to obey it cannot be a contempt and there is no power to refer the matter under s 203: Lin v Borrowdale [2011] NSWCA 65; BC201101475 at [58]–[59] per Whealy JA, citing Attorney-General (NSW) v Mayas Pty Ltd (1988) 14 NSWLR 342 at [357] per McHugh JA, Macfarlan & Young JJA at [1]–[2] agreeing.

Whether conduct amounts to contempt will depend upon the circumstances of each case. Examples of conduct found to be contemptuous includes wilful disobedience to a subpoena: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 1) (1991) 25 NSWLR 459 ; a witness' refusal during the trial of a third person to answer questions as directed by the trial judge: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Craven (No 2) (1995) 80 Aust Crim R 272.

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 203.20] Opportunity to submit against a referral

heading.title: Opportunity to submit against a referral

p.text: The judge must ordinarily afford the person an opportunity of showing why the judge should not refer the matter: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 1) (1991) 25 NSWLR 459 at 469 . There is no stipulated procedure to determine that. The person may show the reasons by giving sworn evidence: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 1), aboveat 470, 480 , cf 465. That opportunity is strictly limited to the issue of reference to the Supreme Court: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 1), aboveat 465 .
Legislation cited in [DCA s 203.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 ss 48(2)(i), 49.

The judge may then, in the exercise of the discretion given, refer the matter to the Supreme Court. It is not clear whether it is necessary for the judge to charge the person. It may be that there is no matter to be referred until there is a charge: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 1) (1991) 25 NSWLR 459 at 471 , cf 465. When the reference is made the proceeding will usually be brought by the Registrar of the Supreme Court. The proceedings are usually assigned to the Common Law Division of the Supreme Court ( ss 48(2)(i) and 49 Supreme Court Act): Principal Registrar, Supreme Court of New South Wales v Jando [2001] NSWSC 969; BC200106715 per Studdert J at [2].

Once a matter is referred to the Supreme Court, the Registrar of the Court of Appeal may commence proceedings against the person. The evidence on the hearing will include affidavits from any relevant witnesses. This may include the judge's associate, the tipstaff, the court reporter and the sheriff's officer: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 1) (1991) 25 NSWLR 459 at 480 . While intention is not an essential ingredient of contempt, evidence of intention is relevant: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 1), aboveat 483 . Trial by jury for contempt is obsolete. Summary trial is now the normal procedure: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Willesee [1984] 2 NSWLR 378 at 380, 381, 382; Witham v Holloway (1995) 183 CLR 525 at 534; 131 ALR 401; [1995] HCA 3; BC9506443 ; Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Matthews (No 2) (1999) 32 ACSR 519; [1999] NSWSC 763; BC9904388 per Sackville J.

Where the matter is referred to the Supreme Court there is no prescribed limits on the power to imprison or to fine: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 1) (1991) 25 NSWLR 459 at 479 ; Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 2) (1992) 26 NSWLR 309 at 314 . The range of penalties may include a suspended term of imprisonment: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Matthews (1999) 32 ACSR 404; [1999] FCA 803; BC9903286 . The punishment is to uphold the purpose of the jurisdiction, being the orderly administration of justice according to law. In determining the punishment it is appropriate to bear in mind, punishing the contemnor, deterring the contemnor and others in the future from committing like contempts, and denouncing the conduct in an appropriately emphatic way: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 2), aboveat 314 . The evidence relevant to penalty includes evidence as to the good character and personal circumstances of the person: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 2), aboveat 312 ; in the case a witness' refusal to answer questions — whether the witness was acting on legal advice: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Craven (No 2) (1995) 80 Aust Crim R 272.

All charges of contempt must be proved beyond reasonable doubt, whether the contempt is characterised as civil or criminal: Witham v Holloway (1995) 183 CLR 525 at 534.5, 535.5; 131 ALR 401 at 410–11; [1995] HCA 3; BC9506443 .

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 203.45] Breach of orders made without power

heading.title: Breach of orders made without power

p.text: If an inferior court (such as the District Court) has no power to make an order, the failure to obey it is not a contempt. If however the order is made within the Court's power but improperly made, the order is effective until set aside by a superior court and while it exists must be obeyed: Attorney-General (NSW) v Mayas Pty Ltd (1988) 14 NSWLR 342 at 357D ; United Telecasters Sydney Ltd v Hardy (1991) 23 NSWLR 323 at 335C ; Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435 at 442 [17] , 453 [55]; 162 ALR 336 at 340, 348; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 .

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 203.50] Punishment — failure to give evidence

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 203.50] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act 1999 s 4.
(NSW) Sentencing Act 1989.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Pt 55 r 13.

In Wood v Staunton (No 5) (1995) 86 A Crim R 183 at 185; BC9601224 , Dunford J identified ten matters (taken in part from Registrar, Court of Appeal v Gilby (NSWCA, Mahoney, Priestley and Clarke JJA, 20 August 1991, unreported, BC9101644) and applied by Studdert J in Principal Registrar, Supreme Court of New South Wales v Jando [2001] NSWSC 969; BC200106715 at [18] ) to be addressed in determining punishment where there has been a refusal to answer questions or give evidence, namely: (1) the seriousness of the contempt proved; (2) whether the contemnor was aware of the consequences to himself of what he did; (3) the actual consequences of the contempt on the relevant trial or inquiry; (4) whether the contempt was committed in the context of serious crime; (5) the reason for the contempt; (6) whether the contemnor has received any benefit by indicating an intention to give evidence; (7) whether there has been any apology or public expression of contrition; (8) the character and antecedents of the contemnor; (9) general and personal deterrence; and (10) denunciation of the contempt. Contempt, though a common law offence for which there is no statutory maximum penalty, is an offence within the meaning of s 4 Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act 1999 — which Act applies to a sentence of imprisonment for contempt of court (as did its predecessor the Sentencing Act 1989 : Attorney-General (NSW) v Whiley (1993) 31 NSWLR 314 at 320–21 ): Principal Registrar, Supreme Court of New South Wales v Jando [2001] NSWSC 969; BC200106715 at [42], [45] . If a contemnor is punished by a sentence of imprisonment to be served by way of periodic detention then that is a punishment which can properly be considered to be a punishment by committal to a "correctional centre" within the meaning of Pt 55 r 13 SCR: Principal Registrar, Supreme Court of New South Wales v Jando [2001] NSWSC 969; BC200106715 at [52] .
